questions.text: A young married couple has been trying to have a child for four years, but without success despite not using any contraceptives. The husband's sperm count is within the normal range. The doctor advised the wife to undergo treatment to enhance fertility. Among the options below, which drug can either stimulate or inhibit ovulation, depending solely on how it's scheduled to be taken?
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Leuprolide

questions.text: A 45-year-old individual named Suresh, who has been diagnosed with insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, has been prescribed insulin therapy. The discomfort from the injections has become unbearable for him, leading him to attempt consuming the insulin orally from the vial that was initially intended for subcutaneous injection. What is the most likely consequence of his action?
questions.correct_answer: C. Chronic high blood sugar levels
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Chronic high blood sugar levels

questions.text: Anil, a 63-year-old male with diabetes, currently on sitagliptin, presents to OPD of GTB hospital with complaints of recurring instances of sinusitis and a sore throat. His fasting blood glucose level is 96 mg/dL. What is the most plausible explanation for these symptoms?

options.label: C
options.text: Side effect related to his medication

questions.correct_answer: C. Side effect related to his medication
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Side effect related to his medication

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman, diagnosed with osteoporosis, is visiting her doctor for a standard check-up. She is currently taking risedronate. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?

options.label: B
options.text: Inhibition of enzymes involved in mevalonate pathway of cholesterol biosynthesis

questions.correct_answer: B. Inhibition of enzymes involved in mevalonate pathway of cholesterol biosynthesis
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Inhibition of enzymes involved in mevalonate pathway of cholesterol biosynthesis

questions.text: Considering the standard roles of triiodothyronine (T3) and thyroxine (T4) in a young female presenting with hypothyroidism, which of the following assertions is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The absorption of T3 is reduced by food consumption

options.label: B
options.text: The hormones are broken down through the microsomal P450 system

options.label: C
options.text: Phenytoin slows down the metabolism of thyroid hormones

options.label: D
options.text: Rifampin slows down the metabolism of thyroid hormones

questions.correct_answer: B. The hormones are broken down through the microsomal P450 system
questions.explanation: Ans. B. The hormones are broken down through the microsomal P450 system

questions.text: A 25-year-old boy sustains a shoulder injury in a road side accident. Despite using the NSAIDs, he's still struggling with pain and swelling. When he enquires about glucocorticoid injections, his doctor begins discussing the wide range of glucocorticoid effects on the body. In what ways could glucocorticoids potentially assist this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Reducing the activity of phospholipase A2

options.label: B
options.text: Enhancing healing through increased collagen production

questions.correct_answer: A. Reducing the activity of phospholipase A2
questions.explanation: Ans. A. Reducing the activity of phospholipase A2

questions.text: Raju, a 50-year-old male is experiencing rapid heart rate, intolerance to heat, tremors, and unexpected weight loss. Her thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels are significantly elevated. He was prescribed a medication to block the release of TSH. Which medication is this?
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Octreotide

questions.text: Metformin is least likely to reduce blood sugar in which of the following patients?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Non-diabetics

Explanation:

  • • A. Obese diabetics
  • • A. Obese diabetics
  • • Metformin is particularly effective in obese diabetics because it helps reduce insulin resistance and can aid in weight management, both of which are beneficial in managing type 2 diabetes.
  • • C. Type 2 diabetics
  • • C. Type 2 diabetics
  • • Metformin is a first-line treatment for type 2 diabetes and is effective in reducing blood sugar levels in these patients by addressing the underlying pathophysiological mechanisms of the disease.
  • • D. Diabetics not responding to sulfonylureas
  • • D. Diabetics not responding to sulfonylureas
  • • Metformin can be effective in diabetics who do not respond to sulfonylureas. It works through different mechanisms, so it can be beneficial as monotherapy or in combination with other antidiabetic medications, including when sulfonylureas alone are insufficient.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Metformin is a widely used antihyperglycemic agent for managing type 2 diabetes, particularly effective in patients with insulin resistance, such as obese diabetics. It works by decreasing hepatic glucose production and improving insulin sensitivity. However, in non-diabetic individuals, metformin is least likely to reduce blood sugar levels significantly, as their glucose metabolism is generally normal.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of oxytocin?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Hyperprolactinemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Oxytocin is primarily used for the induction or augmentation of labor and the management of postpartum hemorrhage due to its ability to stimulate uterine contractions. It is not indicated for the treatment of hyperprolactinemia, which is managed with dopamine agonists.

questions.text: A 70-year-old postmenopausal woman presents to your clinic with persistent lower back pain for the last three months. She reports the pain is gradually increasing in intensity. The pain is non-radiating and does not change with position or activity. She denies trauma or any other symptoms. Her medical history is notable for hypertension and type 2 diabetes. Her only medications are lisinopril and metformin. Her BMI is 28. A dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan reveals a T-score of -2.7 at the lumbar spine. Laboratory tests show normal calcium, phosphate, and vitamin D levels. You start her treatment with the drug of choice for this condition. Which of the following is the most likely side effect of this drug?
questions.explanation: Ans. A. Osteonecrosis of the jaw

questions.text: Which of the following drug can decrease bone resorption as well as increase bone formation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Romosozumab

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of Other Options
  • • A. Denosumab
  • • A. Denosumab
  • • Denosumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits RANKL (receptor activator of nuclear factor kappa-Β ligand), leading to decreased bone resorption. It does not significantly increase bone formation. Denosumab is used primarily to prevent bone loss in conditions like osteoporosis and certain cancers.
  • • C. Teriparatide
  • • C. Teriparatide
  • • Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone (PTH) that primarily stimulates bone formation. It is used to treat osteoporosis by increasing bone formation but does not significantly decrease bone resorption. Teriparatide is typically reserved for patients with severe osteoporosis or those who have not responded to other treatments.
  • • D. Cinacalcet
  • • D. Cinacalcet
  • • Cinacalcet is a calcimimetic agent used to treat secondary hyperparathyroidism in patients with chronic kidney disease and hypercalcemia in patients with parathyroid carcinoma. It lowers parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels by increasing the sensitivity of calcium-sensing receptors in the parathyroid gland. Cinacalcet does not directly affect bone resorption or formation.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Romosozumab uniquely decreases bone resorption and increases bone formation by inhibiting sclerostin. In contrast, denosumab decreases bone resorption by inhibiting RANKL, teriparatide increases bone formation as a recombinant PTH, and cinacalcet lowers PTH levels without directly affecting bone metabolism.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman, Seema was a resident of Nubra Valley in Leh Ladakh. She underwent a kidney transplant at AIIMS, Delhi. After transplant she was started several immunosuppressant drugs, including daily prednisone. She had returned to her home at Nubra Valley and is taking prednisone for the past two months since her transplant. However, she is trapped in her house due to heavy snow and may soon run out of prednisone. What health risk is she most likely to face if she does not get her prednisone in time?
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Cardiovascular collapse

questions.text: A 45-year-old sexually active female approaches her family doctor seeking a contraceptive. She is a chronic smoker consuming around a pack of cigarettes daily. She also consumes few alcoholic drinks per week. She has no personal or family history of breast, ovarian, or endometrial cancer. What could be the reason for her physician to advise against using a contraceptive containing estrogen?

options.label: B
options.text: The potential for estrogen to disrupt the patient's lipid profile like increasing LDL cholesterol, leading to an elevated risk of cardiovascular disease

options.label: C
options.text: High risk of developing endometrial cancer

questions.explanation: Ans. D. Increased risk of thromboembolism

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman with a medical history of diabetes, hypertension, rheumatoid arthritis and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) has been feeling tired for the past 2 weeks. Her current medication regimen includes glipizide, prednisone, telmisartan, and pantoprazole. Her complete blood count shows an elevated white blood cell count with predominant neutrophilia. Which of her medications could potentially be the reason for her increased TLC and neutrophilia?
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Prednisone

questions.text: A young couple is having trouble conceiving after nine months of unprotected intercourse. The wife's levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) are normal, and her pelvic exam shows no abnormalities. They agree to a trial of letrozole in hopes of increasing their chances of conception. How does letrozole work?

options.label: C
options.text: It blocks estrogen receptors in the hypothalamus

questions.explanation: Ans. A. It inhibits aromatase

questions.text: In the given diagram, identify the site of action of sodium iodide as antithyroid drug?
questions.explanation: Ans. D. D

questions.text: A 54-year-old man has insulin-dependent diabetes. He desires to take insulin glargine because of its efficacy and ease of dosing. This would be represented as which of the following labels on the above diagram?
questions.explanation: Ans. D. D

questions.text: Which of the following statements about dapagliflozin is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Its major mode of action in diabetes mellitus is to cause glucosuria when serum glucose is above 180 mg/dL.

options.label: B
options.text: It acts by inhibiting SGLT2 present in collecting tubules of the nephron

options.label: C
options.text: Urinary tract infections are common with its use

questions.correct_answer: C. Urinary tract infections are common with its use
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Urinary tract infections are common with its use

questions.text: Which of the following statements about elagolix is false?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a gonadotropin release hormone antagonist

options.label: C
options.text: It is approved for treatment of pain due to endometriosis

options.label: D
options.text: It can cause hot flashes as adverse effect

questions.correct_answer: B. It is not effective orally
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. It is not effective orally

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Elagolix is an orally active gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) antagonist approved for the treatment of moderate to severe pain associated with endometriosis. It effectively reduces the production of gonadotropins and estrogen, which can alleviate endometriosis-related pain. However, its estrogen-lowering effect can lead to side effects such as hot flashes. Understanding the pharmacokinetics, therapeutic indications, and potential adverse effects of elagolix is crucial for its appropriate use in clinical practice.

questions.text: Which of the following drug acts as Selective Estrogen Receptor Downregulator?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Fulvestrant

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Selective Estrogen Receptor Downregulators (SERDs) like fulvestrant are used in the treatment of hormone receptor-positive metastatic breast cancer by promoting the degradation of estrogen receptors and reducing estrogen-mediated signaling. Raloxifene, a Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator (SERM), and mifepristone, a progesterone receptor antagonist, have different mechanisms of action and therapeutic uses.
